comments.commentBody: It should have been BOY. We all would have loved that.

Poor comprehension of the article, or, maybe it's the water in Nevada, or, the coyotes: Ms. Santiago's rent is quoted in the top paragraphs as $703/month, and she is current with payments. So, it's NOT rent free.

You said: "I know exactly what the son and mom cooked up." Wow - what's your crystal ball model, please share where did you buy it - I want one, too.

No I didn't watch the video. I much prefer reading articles online. Glad they mentioned the documentary.

The "lawyers are scum" and "people sue too much" meme has been pushed by some with big vested interests. How can you right about this incident without mentioning this AMAZING documentary?

The Times is far too polite with this analysis.  First, if the wronged parties were sophisticated institutions, then why should $4 billion be confiscated from JPM for underwater homeowners?  Also, exactly why are sophisticated investors being compensated for this alleged fraud?  Mom and Pop Smith were not buying CDOs and specific tranches of Bear Stearns MBS pools.  If sophisticated investors like Fannie and Freddie executed bad trades in bonds they supposedly had the intellectual ability to analyze, how is it that JPM stockholders are footing the bill for their incompetence?  And finally, JPM did the nation a favor with Bear, which Dimon initially wanted no part of.  He finally acquiesced after repeated requests from Treasury.  All in all this blatant, politicized attack on a pillar of US capitalism reflects the hostility of the Administration towards the Street, and it's need to throw some red meat to its left wing base.  Where these shakedowns go next is anyone's guess, but reports today of new investigations by the CFTC into FX market are a preview of the Administration's next witch hunt.
Completely wrong as I have previous demonstrated on many occasions.

I'm all for making significant changes in higher education.

I like the idea of getting rid of the 'extra-curriculars' but how exactly would that be accomplished among the private school set? And in a free market, why have the 'extras' been flourishing?

I'm not sure about the idea of reducing administration. Do you have any idea what these folks do? Let me tell you about some of our hires in recent years: they raise money externally from donors, they oversee and staff career centers, they help students with financial aid, they oversee the involvement of technology (do you have any idea how much 'adminstration' goes into creating and managing online courses?). I could go on and on and on. But looking at a line-item on budgets from the outside looking int, and simply saying "let's nix that" is silly.

As for tying graduation rates to funding: while I desperately want the graduation rates to go up, I worry that the suggested solution will simply lower the standards...just so everyone gets pushed through. We already see this in droves. The reality is so very very many are simply not equipped for college because of their former public education. Requiring colleges to just push them through the way the prior public education system likely did, doesn't help anyone. The whole thing becomes a joke.
No, Adrian O, you fail to understand the data.  Decade by decade, every decade has been warmer than the one before beginning with the 1960s.
Read "Plows, Plagues and Petroleum" by W.F. Ruddiman.  Also his new book, with further data and elaboration, due out this month.
See my reply to Matt about the same point.  I stand by the climatologists conclusions.

All the above commentaries are testaments to the Economic views of professor r.d.wolff. He clearly explains the economic history of our current problems.

Efficient productivity, computers, robots and off shoring are rendering human labor unnecessary. Plenty of need for farm laborers but everyone is too soft for this work except for Mexican immigrants.

College, public and private, is so expensive and half the majors are worthless in the job market. Worse are the run for profit tech and nursing businesses, poor training and big debts, lucky if you get a job at half ofthe pay that they indicate.

Personally, I recommend being an opportunistic scam artist. Real Estate, mortgage broker, insurance sales, phony health and exercise nostrums. Then take the cash and flip houses or keep them and collect rents.
I will not be much in evidence here @ DotEarth for last least the next week.  Others will have to take up the burden of pointing out just how vastly wrong wmar, Adrian O, etc. are.
If Ryan did tip the refs, then we should tip our hats to him.

I should stop being surprised.

The only point not mentioned, andI suppose it was from pure modesty, is that the liqueur is made from a secret recipe of 130 Herbs. Ach! One way I've had it is with just a few drops in hot chocolate, very nice, really.

For a while, a white chartreuse was also produced; when Martin mentioned chartreuse for Deb's hair colour, that's what I thought of it turning. Not that we'd have anything to do with that, oh no.

"healing of the financial system"  What does that mean? It seems the banks are pretty healthy!  And why not since we not only bailed them out directly (that's "we the people") and indirectly by bailing out AIG. That also again was ("We the people").  Could it possibly refer to healing the overall relationship that banks as lending institutions should have to a strong economy? (hint: Glass/Steagall), or well...maybe it means a total return to "business as usual", where regulators turn a blind eye to dangerously speculative bank investment strategies that put insured deposit funds at risk, backed by , of course ("we the people") and then accept whatever explanations, computer models and other data provided by the banks as trustworthy.  So again, what does healing the financial system mean?  Maybe it means having funds available to home buyers, or home owners trying to refinance, and small businesses.  But no, it seems to be providing cheap money from the Fed to allow corporations and banks to pad their balance sheets and continue the corporate casino until it crashes again.  Yep, healing well.

Don't get too comfy till we see single pay and obtaining meds and common items based on quantity procurement. The thugs that run the take money and deny game have become very hooked on those seven or more figure incomes. They'll find a way to ding this. Remain vigilant.

That is not at all surprising.  A friend in Kentucky who had bypass surgery last year with a wife with a connective tissue disease was able to trade in their high-deductible $1300-per-month policy that didn't cover squat for a $700-per-month gold plan.  I read an article in a San Francisco newspaper where a couple of people were complaining about paying MORE for health insurance.  One reported paying nearly $10,000 more per year for a family of four.  I checked on the California exchange, and if this person was telling the truth (which I doubt), it would mean that he had been getting an individual policy for his family of four for $325 per month prior to the PPACA.  Frankly, if that were really true, it certainly must have been a high-deductible policy that didn't cover squat.  As Ezra Klein over at Wonk blog has pointed out, many that claim to pay more are comparing apples to oranges.  After all, how can you compare a high-deductible policy with all sorts of exclusions to a comprehensive policy that covers everything?  Or worse, what about those policies that were sold with a lifetime cap of $50,000 or $75,000?  I have no idea what a person who actually got sick under that type of coverage was supposed to do--after all, the inadequacy of such caps would not become evident until a person actually got sick.  I remember having a policy 14-15 years ago with a million-dollar cap.  I could not imagine spending that much on health care, and yet, it still made me nervous.

As a side effect of moving from a group plan to individual plans will be extra social security and medicare payroll taxes when we increase salaries to pay for the individual policies that replace the current 100% company paid insurance premium.  If that is the common response to the ACA, it should give a boost to both.

This may not have anything to do with sock puppets but I finally got my new health insurance quotes today.  For a 55 year old man in Oregon, roughly equivalent coverage for an individual plan in 2014 is 63% of the cost of the small group plan we had in 2013.  This is the no subsidy cost since both I and my employees earn a too much to qualify.  Cruz was right, we are going to get hooked on all that sugary sweetness.

uh, actually, Landis' career and life kind of fell apart after he was stripped of the title...and getting back into racing was actively blocked by then-current dopers.  it's a real shame that HE was a HUGE loser in this idiocy while the sheep praised Armstrong's purity, when the latter was a vociferous self-interested PR machine who took NO prisoners.  (still i think he should have his 7 titles)

Heisenberg,

Please reread my original post. I said during the rampant use of anabolic steroids top cyclist had much increased upper-body muscle mass. When comprehensive PED testing was instituted, the upper-bodies of the riders looked like they did pre-steroid use that probably began in the mid-70's. It is very easy to tell when steroids are being used. One only has to look at pictures of an athlete year-to-year. A sudden increase of muscle mass is a dead giveaway.

People focus on Armstrong, but it was his entire team that escaped detection for seven years.  The test procedures were a joke, and the evidence strongly suggests that the incompetence was intentional.
so your personal experience represents everyone's experience?

I am sick and tired of commentators who peg college graduation to salary rates.  I attended an Ivy League college (Columbia) with an insatiable desire to learn, not to make money. Fortunately, because of my high school academic (not athletic) achievement, I attended college without parental support (my father wanted me to find a job), but enabled by such things as S.A.T. scores nationally in the top 1/2 of 1%.  Columbia gave me a full-ride Charles Hayden Memorial Scholarship, for which I will always be grateful.  Then, in my freshman year, I was bowled over by Columbia's Core Curriculum, which has nothing to do with vocational training but provided a breath-taking view of the civilization into which I had been born, one which has formed the core of my subsequent experiences, my intellectual life, and my professional achievements. The totality of my educational experiences was more than useful, it was exhilarating. The thudding mediocrity of students who plod through college to "get a job" is alien not only to the creative mind, but the civilized sensibility.  Yes, upon completion of my doctorate, a publishing contract in hand, I landed my first job on the faculty of one of America's top universities, and I began my adult life not with a "job," but with an intoxicating sense of adventure.  Woe to those who tell our youth to plod through life for coins, when they deserve the joy of an adventure.
Spellcheck fail, read tortellINI.
We did read it that way, Bru.

One hundred bonus points to Bru for referencing "Sue Me, Sue You Blues."

Ringo's "Early 1970" is a less dour take on the break-up of the Beatles.

Princess of Power, SHERA, was a rockstar in our house in the early 80's, a favorite of all my kids. Even WITH THAT answer confidently filed away in the gimme category there were still a few never heard ofs that needed the assistance of crosswords to reveal themselves. 32d, SHIRR, ENTR 'acte and the legal speak IN REM were the vaguest of the lot. The latter of the four had me humming George Harrison's "Sue Me, Sue You Blues" after ascertaing its' meaning. The tune was George's take on the Beatles struggle with Apple Corps. and the band's woes resulting from its' dealings with Apple Records. Interesting how forty years ago there was a little bit of Wordplay going on in the courtroom...27d reminded me of author Christopher...ERROL Morris had me lost in the fog and similarly the Vader/ANI connection...I had Vicks at first for HALLS...Overall the puzzle had a nice down to EARTH feel to it and was fun to solve.

Spinach TortolINI

Parents who are not fluent in English should speak to their children in their native language. The language ability of children will improve with rich, naturalistic communication regardless of which "language" is used. Imagine how many fewer different words and how stilted the conversation would be if an adult who spoke poor English chose to speak only English to her child.

Both common sense and research shows that we humans learn when we have positive emotions toward the subject matter or toward the teacher. The words spoken to a child carry emotional messages, and these make a difference.  If the message is "I care about you; I'm excited about the world around us; I'm eager for you to learn about it," the child will learn.  If the emotional message shows lack of engagement with the child, the child will not learn. Many under-paid, under-educated staff in preschools don't talk much to their own children; can we expect them to talk with warmth and care in the classroom?
Imagine parents parenting.

Actually, it doesn't matter what language the parents use as long as they interact with their children in ways that prepare them for school. Contrary to what we used to believe, knowing a home language is not a disadvantage; it's an advantage. Bilingualism has many positive effects on learning and on the brain.
